mutant_detection_ability.analysis: The test has strong mutant detection through specific value checks (0u, 0xFFFFFFFFu) and determinism validation. Would catch changes to hash computation logic, XOR operations, and result values. The test of all-zeros→zero and all-ones→non-zero would detect bitwise operation errors. However, it wouldn't catch subtle loop boundary issues or internal lookup table corruption since it doesn't validate intermediate states.

overall_assessment.summary: High-quality test with strong assertions, excellent structure, and good mutant detection capability.
strengths: Clear Arrange-Act-Assert structure with well-organized test cases
Specific value assertions (0u, 0xFFFFFFFFu) that validate exact expected behavior
Tests both edge cases (all zeros, all ones) and normal inputs
Validates determinism explicitly by repeating computation
Excellent comment-to-code conformity - description matches actual behavior
No flakiness risks - pure deterministic function testing
Good naming that describes the scenario clearly
weaknesses: Doesn't test offset parameter (always uses offset=0)
Could test more input variations to catch loop boundary issues
Numbers in input arrays (0x01, 0x02, etc.) could be named constants for clarity
Doesn't explicitly verify that different input patterns produce different hashes beyond two cases

recommendations.action: Consider extracting test input arrays to named constants to improve readability (e.g., const uint8_t SIMPLE_INPUT[] = {0x01, 0x02, 0x03, 0x04})
Add one test case with non-zero offset to exercise that parameter path (note: this is covered by HashWithOffset test in the suite)
